This throws exceptions, which is why it was replaced a while ago.  Why was it added back?
Ack

Please don't do this.  Doing so causes you to not handle errors at all.

Also, variants can only throw in the case of unfilled-by-exception, which we should never see.

This was done to fix the clang-tidy error. Move and visit are called from no-except functions. Yes, in our case variant will always hold some value. That is why the catch is empty. But clang-tidy will show it as Error if don't catch possible exceptions. This wrapper works as exception-safe version of std::visit. The wrapper added to avoid ugly try-catch everywhere std::visit is performed.

Understood, I would like to see how we can avoid this complexity of having a templated, non-trivial class.  I suspect it will be quite a few iterations of using get_if rather than std::visit, and I'm ok with that.  That seems significantly less complex to me.

I wonder if this is a place where we should be using boost::variant, which I don't believe requires valueless by exception.  Might be something to consider, although I suspect get_if will work better.

I felt adding "if else" chain everywhere to do the same thing for different types reduces the readability and maintainability. I have removed Template class with a generic function to do the same. is it ok?

> I felt adding "if else" chain everywhere to do the same thing for different types reduces the readability and maintainability. 

As the maintainer of this project, I disagree.  Having concrete types helps to review code faster, as you don't have to hunt for every possible type an lvalue can be.  Please make the change as I've requested.

I disagree on this. To me it is against the spirit of generic programming and " dont repeat yourself (DRY)" principle. I think we can agree to disagree here. 
I will make changes as per the request.

> I disagree on this.

Your disagreement is noted, and I'm happy to revisit if we get N different implementations of this.  Part of the reason I'm arguing for this is I know that we will likely only have 3 body implementations, and we've been through several rounds where people write "generic" code, and duplicate quite a bit of code in the binary.  If we get to 3 body implementations, and this use of generics doesn't duplicate a lot of code, I'm happy to discuss again then.

> To me it is against the spirit of generic programming and " dont repeat yourself (DRY)" principle. I think we can agree to disagree here. 
> I will make changes as per the request.

Thank you, I appreciate it.

THere's no needs to do BOTH holds_alternative and std::visit.  I'm having a little trouble even understanding what this function is doing.  Can you help me understand here?

This code does the body migration (string-body to file-body or file-body to string-body).
Use Case;
1) current response type is string-body
2) user updates some header fields of the response
3) Then the user tries to open a file
4) The body should be migrated to file-body
5) Before setting the file-body to variant, we need to copy all headers from string-body to the new file-body

The same code work for file-body to string-body migration as well.

The hold_alternative check prevents migration from file-body to file-body, or string-body to string-body. Similar to how we avoid self-assignment in "=" operator overloading.

> This code does the body migration (string-body to file-body or file-body to string-body).
> Use Case;
> 1) current response type is string-body
> 2) user updates some header fields of the response
> 3) Then the user tries to open a file
> 4) The body should be migrated to file-body
> 5) Before setting the file-body to variant, we need to copy all headers from string-body to the new file-body
> 
> The same code work for file-body to string-body migration as well.
> 
> The hold_alternative check prevents migration from file-body to file-body, or string-body to string-body. Similar to how we avoid self-assignment in "=" operator overloading.
Please make the code simpler to read.
Ack
std::get throws.  Please use the result of the emplace() call as your return.
we are making sure that the variant will have proper value at updateAlternative function. Should we still use get_if here?
I never said to use get_if.  I said to use the result of emplace()

The most important thing is that body() can now return an error, which means that the prototype of this function needs to change.  As-is, you've just make this code throw, which this code doesn't catch anywhere, and will just crash the service.

emplace will not be executed always. It executes only if the current body type is not the desired type. So we should call get or get_if in other cases. Made changes to use safeVisit to avoid the exception.
Per the coding standard documented in Developing.md please do not use exceptions for recoverable errors, which this is.

But how do make a non-breaking change here? The body() should return a reference to a string.  If we change the return type to include error-info then the change set will be huge. We should handle the error in every calling site. Do we really want to do it? And how do we handle the error case in the calling site? I felt the simplest solution would be to make sure that no such case occur. That is what updateResponseIfNeeded function do. The only issue is that the "get" can throw, but it will never throw in our case.

> But how do make a non-breaking change here?

Because prior to this commit we did not use exceptions for non-exceptional (Ie, should not crash) error handling.  This uses exceptions for non-exceptional error handling.

> The body() should return a reference to a string.  If we change the return type to include error-info then the change set will be huge.

"This requires a large change" is not an argument against not handling errors.  Errors shall be handled.  Also, there aren't that many calls to body(), I would expect about a dozen.

> We should handle the error in every calling site. Do we really want to do it? 

Yes, we should handle errors.

> And how do we handle the error case in the calling site? I felt the simplest solution would be to make sure that no such case occur.

The case can occur.  It is trivial to write code in a handler that does this incorrectly, which means it's an error that needs handled.

> That is what updateResponseIfNeeded function do. The only issue is that the "get" can throw, but it will never throw in our case.

How have you verified that it can never throw?

How have you verified that it can never throw?
Standard says so.
std::bad_variant_access is the type of the exception thrown in the following situations:

std::get(std::variant) called with an index or type that does not match the currently active alternative
std::visit called to visit a variant that is valueless_by_exception

We are making sure that variant has value before calling get.


The case can occur. It is trivial to write code in a handler that does this incorrectly, 
How? if we make sure that new strigbody will be created and set before returning

Please don't call this "alternative".  Probably make it not a template, and call the method:

modifyTypeToFile()

It is better to keep this as a generic function for all types. Otherwise we will be duplicating the same code for each type. Templates are useful for wrting such reusable algorithms. What do you think?

> It is better to keep this as a generic function for all types. 

I don't agree.

> Otherwise we will be duplicating the same code for each type.

This is intentional, because the code will get duplicated at compile time.  It's intended to be a hint to the writer that things might need to be optimized into functions.
I don't understand. Are you saying that prefer handwritten duplicate code over generic functions? Generic functions are invented to avoid such duplicated hand-written code right?

> Are you saying that prefer handwritten duplicate code over generic functions?

Yes.

> Generic functions are invented to avoid such duplicated hand-written code right?

This project has never optimized for amount of code.  It optimizes for simplicity.  Generics are quite useful if there are N implementations, where N is large, but with only 2 implementations, a branch is much simpler.

Also, FWIW, now that we have if constexpr, most implementations of generics have been moving to a branch-like generic for simplicity.

the majority of what this is testing is boost things, which really should be going into the boost test harness, not bmcweb.  We shouldn't be inventing a serialization step just to test it.  If we want to test the serialization, we can do it with HttpConnection.  The only bmcweb class I see tested here is Response, in which case, we should just be testing the response interfaces themselves.   I think the whole writeMessage path can be removed.
